428, 429. (L.)
Anthony Barber
and
John Merryjohn
, were indicted for
stealing 65 pounds weight of sugar, value 15 s. the property of persons unknown, August 1 . ++

Barnaby Linton
. I am a constable for the West-India merchants; I am bound over to see this properly carried on. I know nothing of the affair.

- Macdaniel. The first of last month, between three and four in the morning, the two men at the bar were coming along the streets; there was another man with them, all with sugar; I was sitting at my box (I am a watchman) in Tower-street; I took hold of the first man, and asked him what he had got there; he said, what was that to me; I said, I must know; the other man came up to his assistance; the beadle was looking over the hatch; I called out; he came, we took the two prisoners, the other man ran away, after dropping the sugar he had in the street; they had 65 pounds weight of sugar in all. It was brown clear sugar.

William Cannon
. On the 1st of August, between four and five in the morning, Macdaniel had hold of the prisoner Merryjohn, the other got away; he called, stop thief; I stopped Barber, and brought him to the watch-house; he had a parcel of sugar upon him.

Jacob Gray
. I am a watchman; between three and four in the morning on the first of last month, I saw my partner engaged with three men; they made an attempt to run away; we secured the two prisoners, the other got away.

Joseph Richards
. I am under beadle of the ward; about 20 minutes after three on the 1st of August, three men came up to the place where we had a centry stood; I heard a noise; Macdaniel called to me to come to him; I went to him; Merryjohn had thrown down the sugar; I ordered a watchman to take it up, and I laid hold of Merryjohn to carry him to the watch-house; one ran quite off, the other attempted to run but was soon taken, and we took them to the watch-house.

William Hummer
. I am a constable; I took these two prisoners into custody; the account they gave of the sugar was, that it was sweepings, but it did not appear so to us, it was clean sugar.
A man gave the sugar to me to hold while he made water, the watchman stopped me immediately, and he ran away.

John Pawles
Miller. I live in White's-yard, Rosemary lane; I have known Barber about twelve months.
Q. How does he get his bread?
Miller. He goes a portering, sometimes one way, sometimes another; Merryjohn and he live together; they are Venetians, honest people as far as I know.

I had been to Billingsgate that morning; I saw a man in the street, he asked me what countryman I was; I said, a Genoese; he wanted me to carry the sugar; I took it to carry; the watchman stopped me, and that man got away.
